text: What is Council and how do I use it?

choices.text: Council is an app that helps you talk through things with yourself. Sometimes, just reading your choices back to yourself helps with thinking about a situation.
choices.imageTitle: Young Female Fox near Galbraith Lake Camp 08/1973

choices.text: In programming, this is sometimes called "rubber duck debugging" because you can literally explain your problem and options for dealing with it to a rubber duck. However, it can apply to many other kinds of decision making situations, big and small, from "What should I make for dinner?" to "Should I interview for this job?" This process is useful even for topics you don't even want a single correct answer for, like "Who is the best cat?"
choices.imageTitle: Shorebird wading in Upper Newport Bay, near Newport Beach, May 1975

choices.text: In Council, you write out your "problem" (or topic) and the choices you have to respond to it with. Then, you send it before a council! The council is just images of beings from various public domain image sources, like The British Library and the Library of Congress. Each choice is presented by a different council member. It's like when NPCs in a video game like Baldur's Gate II or King of Dragon Pass all pipe up with advice for you! Hopefully, this changes your perspective a little, or at least makes your possible choices easier to read.
choices.imageTitle: Official Portrait of Buddy the Dog: 04/22/1998

choices.text: To view all of your problems, you can click on "All Problems" at the bottom of every view.
choices.imageTitle: Wild Deer in Garner State Park 07/1972

choices.text: To add a new problem, you can click "Add new problem" at the bottom of the All Problems view.

In the editing view, click on the Problem text to edit it, then click outside of it to complete editing. (Later on, you'll be able to hit Cmd+Enter to complete.) Click "Add choice" to add a new choice, then click on the choice to edit it. Finally, you can view it with a council by click "Send before a council"!
In the council view, you can click "Change council" to get a new council if you'd like your stuff presented to you by a fresh council.
choices.imageTitle: Porcupine in tree Great Sand Dunes National Monument, 05/1972.

choices.text: Your problems are all kept locally in your browser. They are not shared anywhere else.
choices.imageTitle: Youngsters wash their horses in Upper Newport Bay in Orange County, May 1975

choices.text: Have fun and enjoy your councils! Email jimkang@gmail.com or tweet @deathmtn if you have questions.
